commentBody: NYT needs to resynchronize their server clocks. This puzzle was over a minute late. Never used to happen, been happening a lot lately

Solid puzzle. If I had to pick some nits, I didn‚Äôt love ‚ÄúNEWAT‚Äù ‚Äî just feels awkward to me, like I need it to be NEWTO for some reason. And the clue for STARSTRUCK feels a bit goofy? Like I feel as though most people might be starstruck meeting tswift, you know?

Sam, 

I assume you know that William Butler YEATS not only spells his name differently from the slangy verb, but also pronounces it Yates, so that it neither rhymes with either YEETS nor that other poet, Keats.
I done did this puzz

In the Ozarks, "yeet" is a question.

Yeet?

Yup, I'm full.

On the importance of commas: I missed the one in 57A's clue so had "at all" for "however briefly". Got rid of it when the crosses didn't work (well, NAFTA still did, but not the last two) and noticed the comma finally. 

Now, let's eat, Grandma...

I had a blast with this space themed puzzle. AURORA was a nice little extra cosmos themed answer. In a weird coincidence, I happened to be listening to Astral Weeks while solving.  Must have something out there in the universe.

BLACKHOLESUN is a fine song.  There‚Äôs an interesting version by, of all people, Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme.

Being a member of the John Phillip SOUSA Band of Colorado love Tuba being clued instrument similar to a Sousaphone. Trivia: John Phillip Sousa had the idea of the Sousaphone but J.W. Pepper manufactured the first one. It was created to have something easier to play standing or marching than a tuba.
Got hung up on Sashimi as I was thinking Sushi and put a U first.
A little tricky but fun
Did anyone see DINDIN and visualize a cat instead of a human child?
I absolutely love the phrase GALAXYBRAIN and really wish it was making its debut in a themeless for maximum delight. I kind of saw it coming after I got the other theme answers first.
I‚Äôve been waiting for Dingus to show up in the crossword for a very long time. Thank you.
Not a Shakespeare clue in sight, but happy birthday, Will! (Other Will.)

Overall an easy Wed for me. Had a little trouble in the SW corner, but made it through. With SASHIMI crossing LHASA and LIMA, it took the rest of the crosses for me to figure it out. Fun puzzle none the less.

No DRAMA solving this puzzle, and it was very nice to see SOAR, AURORA, and ICARUS in supporting roles. You're a star, Mr. Koppy. Thank you for shining your constructing light upon us earthlings! (Here is Soundgarden's Chris Cornell doing an acoustic version of BLACK HOLE SUN: https://youtu.be/ltc5EsuyBh4?si=CeiXGJFOR6ALJE9i)
Can someone explain the red circled " I " in the Mini Crossword?

I was zoned out on cold medication while doing this puzzle, and wasn't even thinking about a theme until I got to the revealer clue. It was like a splash of cold water... "who... what? Huh?"

I was clearly not in GALAXY BRAIN mode! üòÑ

When I finally gathered my brain cells together I found it a quite clever and fun crossword.

What a delightful Wednesday puzzle!  The answers came  readily, but the way clues related to the theme popped up throughout the puzzle felt like finding little nugget after little nugget of gold in a rippling stream.
In season at our place, we refer to the endless green spears at DINDIN as ASPARAGI.

Another Texas city named after a president is Houston.   First city I thought of before I saw it didn't fit.  Sam Houston was President of the Republic of Texas.   He has a humongous statue in Huntsville, TX.
DIN DIN... Baby speak is in, I'm out.
BLACK HOLE SUN. And just like that, I‚Äôm 18 again (and a bit angsty, in a good way). For that alone, thank you, Brandon. The neat theme is just a cherry on top of that SUNDAE.
Nice. I wasn't familiar with the term "galaxy brain," because I'm old -- but I've googled it and I'm sure I'll run into it all the time now. As one does with new vocabulary.
Um, actually‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ (I am irrationally irritated by 15A. The computer in question originally came in *one* color, Bondi Blue. The second generation of the IMAC was the five-colors version.)

This puzzle had me a bit STAR STRUCK .. üòÜ haven‚Äôt heard DINDIN since my now 30 yr old kiddo was 5 ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è. Fun and very fast solve - beat my Monday time by almost 6 minutes. A puzzle with a cherry on top! üëèüéâ
third time was the charm in terms of spelling ‚Äúlhasa‚Äù correctly. lahso, lahsa, lhasa.
Well, this one will put the stars in your eyes if nothing else well. Trippy puzzle. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V10nYSsaAtY
Call me a DOOFUS, but I never heard of DINGUS before now.  That, along with a couple of other clues, made this Wednesday a PW for me.
Boystown is no more! It's Northalstead now to be more inclusive.

Found this a breeze for a Wednesday, but very enjoyable, thanks! Solved 28 minutes quicker than average, at 17minutes - a new record for a Wednesday (only been x-wording for 4 months so my solve times are definitely higher than most)
Here's the link to Clarkson's "Yeet" (sounds like a designer bourbon, no?): https://youtu.be/wsQH4uHimWM

So, to solve this puzzle you needed to have with pretty high certainty two out of three of knowledge (1) of how to spell LHASA,  (2) that LIMA is a city in Ohio, and (3) of what "yeets" means.  I had only (2), and that without much certainty, so was left at the end of a pretty straightforward puzzle resolving a natick-adjacent 56 Down, which wasn't that hard, but which was also irritating, not very fun, and a bad note to end on because cluing HURLS this just seemed gratuitous to me.
Easier one for me today. No lookups and managed to get the answers I didn‚Äôt know via crosses. Not a PB, but close!

Somewhat frustrating for me, purely because of popular culture references, of which I knew none, which happens sometimes, and unknown DINGUS. I remembered SARAN (instead of cling film) and TAC. 
I nearly revealed the Soundgarden song but persisted with crossers and it revealed itself.

Galaxy brain, nebula award, the gaybar and RPG need to be committed to memory also!
From now on, just call me ‚ÄúGalaxy Brain‚Äù.

Asparagus was an easy one, since it is currently Spargelzeit (asparagus time) in Germany. Everything is asparagus. You can even get asparagus ice cream at some ice cream shops. I enjoyed a delicious cream of asparagus soup at my local Ratskeller just on Monday. Yum!

Anyone likes fun, tricky Thursday puzzles might enjoy May 3, 2008, by Patrick Berry. 

It‚Äôs technically a Saturday puzzle, and my time was a sold Saturday time (on the long side for a Thursday). Once I figured out what was going on, it was pretty easy. 

There are a few names in the SE corner that might be unfamiliar to anyone who wasn‚Äôt around in the 1980s.

Your resident curmudgeon checking in here. 

Did I finish the puzzle in a relatively quick time without having to resort to looking anything up? I did, thanks to the crosses. I know it's un-PC to disparage a puzzle in this hallowed space, but this has to be one of my most-hated puzzles ever. Slang after slang entries. Things that nobody says, ever - BABYCRIB??? It's just a crib. GALAXYBRAIN? Okay, maybe I'm just too old. But this was a total slog.

This puzzle was okay by me.
I enjoyed solving it, Mr. Koppy.

I liked:
‚Ä¢	Having NO NAME in a puzzle with eight.
‚Ä¢	Having AURORA echoing the up-in-the-sky theme.
‚Ä¢	All those schwa-de-vivre enders ‚Äì LHASA, AMELIA, LIMA, AURORA, TUBA, NAFTA, SCUBA, UNA, DRAMA, LOLA, plus partials NEBULA, NOVA, and SCOTIA.
‚Ä¢	TUBE crossing TUBA, not to mention TUBE sharing the puzzle with UNCAP.
‚Ä¢	All the theme answers, which shimmered with spark.
‚Ä¢	The bonus of an extra column.
‚Ä¢	Learning GALAXY BRAIN and more about it after solving.

So, the box you made, Brandon, brought me great pleasure ‚Äì as your puzzles have a habit of doing.  Thank you so much!

A puzzle in which everything was right in my wheelhouse, except for the (substantial) parts that weren't. (How many times have I, personally, linked Weird Al's "Yoda" in these comments?) 67A could have been clued as [Ohio city whose name is pronounced with the accent on the first syllable]. OK, with a population of 1447, it's really more of a village. Here's a 2003 song by the Electric Six, the songwriter of which shares his name with a president and a Texas city. In the video, inexplicably, he dresses up like another president who shares his name with a Texas village (pop. 276): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IslF_EyhMzg *** Just to prove I still have culture, Here's Auden's 1938 poem "Mus√©e des Beaux Arts):
Tac?

Our evening meal on the weekend, with two sub-four-year-old children, was most definitely a din din. But we love ‚Äòem

Anyone else suffering from a tendency more toward black hole brain?

This was a spacy puzzle.
For my song choice, I‚Äôm going with Eddie Vedder‚Äôs cover of ‚ÄúHard Sun‚Äù.
For some reason I had DINkUS for 1D.  kAYBAR seemed like a plausible name for a drinking establishment (a cross between GAYBAR and ka-bar)

Not to pick too small a nit, but...

A DINGbat is a Doofus.
A DINGUS is a Doodad.

You may now return to your regular programming.
Two of my favorite figures from Greek mythology right next to each other, Icarus and Asparagus

Here‚Äôs a fun fact about John Tyler who was president from 1841-1845:  He has a living grandson ! I found that out a few years ago while visiting the Tyler mansion, called Sherwood Forest, in Virginia. Tylers first wife died so he remarried a younger woman and had a son in the 1860s who did the same thing and had a son in the 1920s who still lives.

Fun solve, except I do not love AMO. My heart is with AMI... which is wrong.

Thank you, Brandon

Solving crosswords      .
Constructing crosswords    o
Editing crosswords      O
Mollifying words so they're not so angry all the time   (*)

Zip, zip, zip!  Finis!

Welp, 37A and 13D were varieties of Stumpers!  Thank goodness for crosses.  GALAXY BRAIN is a weird answer, though it makes sense in retrospect....

SOOT before FLUE.

TSK for the clue at 56D...a "new word" I cannot seem to remember because... well, probably in self-defense.  Ugh.  

Don't you wonder why TV and movie people can't just phone the Mayor or Chamber of Commerce in these cities like Taos and LIMA and ask how to pronounce the names?

TYLER is a lovely "City of Roses"--and the park also has an array of dozens and dozens of varieties of Japanese maples.  We visited too early for roses, but just right for azaleas and catalpa trees in bloom.

Lovely puzzle!‚Ä¶ for a Monday! 
Why the editors chose to give us this one on a Wednesday is the real puzzle here. :) 
Nice to cut my regular Wednesday time by more than half, though!
TIL that Lima, OH is pronounced like the bean rather than the city in Peru for which it is named. Ohioans also changed the pronunciation of Cairo, so maybe that's just their thing.
I am worried because Rich in Atlanta hasn't been here for a few days.  I don't recall his applying for leave!
A fun one. My biggest struggle was self inflicted by putting Cod for Cape Cod, instead of Ann. I guess I need to study more Massachusetts geography.
Anyone else mistakenly go see "The Iron Lady" expecting a cool new Marvel movie?
A 1998 video that mentions 2014 and 2015 as well as 2008?

Enjoyable puzzle, thank you!

I was very excited to see the Final Fantasy reference - I‚Äôve got a chocobo decal on my car!
Is a streak of 969 called a Methuselah?  Asking for a friend...
Thanks Brandon Koppy. This was lots of fun.

Some new language I‚Äôm completely unfamiliar with. 

Is GALAXYBRAIN a term now?

Yeets = HURLS??.

Not familiar with NOB having that meaning except with a K in front?

Ooh, Clarkson is the epitome of Marmite taste over here; you either love him or hate him. There is no in between. Where am in the scale? I‚Äôll take that info to my grave.

A nice chewy offering today; hadn‚Äôt come across GALAXY BRAIN before but ok, I‚Äôll buy. I got that the theme was kinda sorta space related.

ASPARAGUS yum yum. Our 2 year old bed is in full swing, producing spears of deliciousness. From next year we‚Äôll be able to pick with abandon, but it‚Äôs two thirds only this season. Perfect with butter and Parmesan.

Query; why is GAYBAR specifically linked with Chicago?
IV "tube"?  That is just not a thing that exists.

I don't feel too bad about looking up "noomi" but I shouldn't have had to read the second paragraph of the Column's Tricky Clues to see that I had misspelled ICARiS!

These things happen when one tries to do a puzzle without Autocheck turned on. But my Phony Streak is now up to 10 days.

I love that this puzzle gave some boomers a hard time. Now you know how us millennials feel almost every puzzle. LOL. I need more puzzles like this. I have thought about taking up the art of crossword puzzle making to just make the ultimate boomer stumper.
wow this is just wonderful thanks!!
Nice enough, but felt like a Monday to me. Maybe I just happened to know the various proper nouns. Never heard of a GALAXYBRAIN, but the theme was so simple this mattered not at all.

Strands #416
‚ÄúWhat a softie!‚Äù

üîµüîµüü°üîµ



NO SPOILERS UNTIL AFTER VIEW ALL REPLIES, PLEASE.
Good one today - funny theme and reveal, and DINGUS is one of my favorite corny insults, so it was entertaining to see that pop up in the prestigious NYTimes crossword!
This puzzle was solved 30,000 feet in the air. By me! (A wonderful distraction from plane sickness.)

I'm pretty sure the *original* iMac was just that blue color, bondi blue, and the five "flavored" ones were sort of second gen.  It's been a while - I had the blueberry one as a home computer, which was a slightly darker blue than the true original.  Anybody else remember that?

Can't believe I immediately knew what "Yeets" meant! Thank you past NYTXword puzzles!  üòÜ

Enjoyed this one. Hadn't heard of GALAXYBRAIN before and I like it! Came in better than average on time. Got a bit slowed because all I could think of for 37A was "there's a little black spot on the sun today" (King of Pain, The Police), which of course doesn't fit and is from 1983, I believe. I'm much more familiar with that one and it just kept playing in my peaBRAIN. But I worked it out. 

Also, stalled by feeling confident (again, thanks to past crosswords) that 19D was either pwns or owns. Finally, I just had to take it out and could see clearly, now the rain has gone... (sorry, great old songs are just coming to me now).  

IVdrip at 46D was another slowdown, but overall, I'm getting better at tearing out what doesn't work. 

Was proud that I waited for a crossing to fill in ANN. I first wanted it to be COD, of course, but I've been fooled by that before. 

We used to have a LHASO Apso named Sasha, so it crossing SASHIMI in the lower right was fun. 

ANDSO, it was a good one for me, with a few slowdowns, but I do like to puzzle out puzzles. ‚ò∫Ô∏è

I wouldn't use 'nob' to mean head in UK
Nob = aristocrat
Knob = unpleasant and annpying person, also knob-head; vulgar and offensive
You get the picture.

Seeing that I watch ‚ÄúThe Hudsucker Proxy‚Äù every year at some point near New Year‚Äôs,
‚Äúdingus‚Äù will always call the late great Paul Newman to mind.
A wordplay lover‚Äôs film from top to bottom, including a crossword constructor scene. Highly recommended.
Loved the Boystown hint! I initially thought it was the iconic club BERLIN but realised it was more generic when I hit the reunified city of the same name. Great puzzle!
A very good one on a Wednesday! Thanks Sam amd Brandon Koppy.

Fun to see Boystown in the puzzle and to read the comments and links.

My dad was a Big Brother and brought his "little" to help me move from Indiana to Cornelia and Wilton in 1998. At some point they took a break from unpacking to take a walk. It didn't occur to me to point them toward Wrigley Field (two blocks NW) and when they came back, he asked if we'd moved to the middle of "gaytown". "Nope," my husband replied, grinning. "Just west."

We loved living between Boystown and Wrigleyville and since I barely recognize the neighborhoods today, I'm happy to see that Reckless Records and The Chicago Diner are still there. (And Chicken Hut! Willie's sounds like a hoot, but we newlyweds were big fans of their half chicken with pita, rice, and salsa for $6.)

Thanks to Mr. Koppy and to the commenters for the fun trip down memory lane. (And with a Soundgarden soundtrack to boot!)
Yeet is just a perfect word.

My usual late puzzle find. A Wednesday from May 16, 2018 by Johnathan Schmalzbach and Bill Albright. A couple of clue/answer examples: "Nickname for a sloppy painter?" TOOLOOSELAUTREC "Nickname for a clumsy composer?" CLODDEBUSSY And some other theme answers: JEWELSVERNE BLAZEPASCAL And the reveal was: FRENCHTWIST Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/16/2018&g=39&d=A ....

DINGUS??  Yeets?

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è
Today's puzzle just spoke to me. Omakase, Final Fantasy, 90s alt-rock, sci-fi, Canada... so many of my favorite things!
I'm glad that Sam is a genius. I found this puzzle pretty tricky. Especially that "Galaxy Brain" is what was supposed to help me solve it.

I loved this puzzle!! It wasn‚Äôt too tough or over-reliant on trivia/proper nouns, and none of the slightly tougher reveals felt like a stretch or an awkward fill. However it had a few that I needed to come back to and think about, which is always nice (when it pays off). 

Well done!!

Loved this puzzle, maybe just because of my age but a ton of the entries clicked with me "Mario Kart", "Yeets", etc. 

I do have to wonder if this would have been better as a Tuesday puzzle since I'm on track to finish it and I found it almost easier than a Monday's!
This one was not my favorite.
Blackhole Sun - best clue of the year.  From a huge Soundgarden fan
I had skybar for 21A for a long time, having never been to Boystown. Should have been more flamboyant. Still I could have never come up with dingus on my own.

@Steven M.

It dropped at exactly 10:00 for me.
@Steve L 9:59:59 here.
We need a Steve J in here immediately.

@N.E. Body I think the only reasonable conclusion is that if you're name is Steven, there's a direct correlation between how late your last initial is in the alphabet and how late the puzzle drops for you
@Steven M. Steven J. Must be a slow solver. He's obviously had it longer.

@Logan
I distinguish "new at" and "new to." "Unfamiliar with"--"I'm new at this kind of puzzle." "Unfamiliar"--"This kind of puzzle is new to me."
@Steve L Interesting, I actually pronounce the word "Yeets" as "Yates." (Kidding. I didn't know about that quirk of pronunciation!)

@Sam Corbin  I just now was going to say what Steve L said (thanks, Steve). I said "Yeets" for half my life (now 85) and discovered the correct pronunciation. As for "yeets," I learned of it from NYT crosswords only in the last year. Sam, your wordplay is great and funny and I like it. Keep it up!

@Steve L
I googled "W. B. Yeats pronunciation" and some hits seemed muddled, but the best explanation rhymed it with "gates".  I always pronounced it "yaytes" which seemed to work.
@Eddie do you want a cookie?

@Paul

Not before DINDIN.

In Texas it's djeet yit?
@Lige something like "yeet yet?" in Baltimore iirc.  Or was it "djeet jet?"?

You mean Balamur?

@Isabeau, thanks I was taking a bit to get that.

Here's her cover from the album *Double Standards*: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hYGa8YeP5BI (You should hear what she does with No Doubt's "I'm Just a Girl," which, knowing DeLaria, is really quite funny!)

Thanks for the recommendation. I did not know she was a singer.

Soundgarden played here a week before he passed, but I had to work and skipped the show. There are plenty of artists I try to see before I can't, but he wasn't on my list. üòû

@Cindy I'm sorry you had to miss the concert. Luckily, there's YouTube, so here are two clips for you from his final shows of that tour, which will give you a taste of his Indianapolis concert: https://youtu.be/VikVUF7ANTU?si=OG9xqjtTTz-Stm3z https://youtu.be/kk8JHFc9VVE?si=EuNVrddpLcGMUfC_

@Marilyn

It‚Äôs a Red Eye. As in 1across and 7 across.
@Marilyn @Menc I never thought of the red eye as a money saver. I always though if it as smart way to fly while being able to sleep at the right time.

@Joya,

Likewise, my parents lived in Kona Hawaii for 30 years, where  the only flight home was a red eye, so it was not a choice.

@DawnW

That‚Äôs such a lovely way to put it.
@DawnW I felt this too. A smooth solve with no lookups for me and only twenty seconds off my record time for a Wednesday. I needed this as I will be on the struggle bus here until Monday's puzzle.
Baby-talk even. Anyway, that's the straw that broke the camel's back.

@Andrzej
Very sorry to hear it. 
Your voice will be missed, and I hope you find your way back.

But even if not, be well.

@Andrzej

Everybody seems fine with "My bad," which sometimes only seems embarrassing to hear a grownup using preschool language, and sometimes makes me gag.

@Andrzej

I‚Äôve enjoyed reading your snippets of Poland. Maybe we‚Äôll see you around again someday

@Andrzej
Sad to see you go! Always enjoyed your contributions to this column.

@Andrzej

So sorry to see you go, but I'm surely with you on this one. Hope you'll read my own comment, soon to appear.
@Andrzej  You can‚Äôt quit now‚Äî you‚Äôre in too deep. It‚Äôs kind of like the mob.
@Grumpy OUCHIE!

@Andrzej

You think you can just walk away?
Hah!
We know where you live!
I tried to post a civil reply but emus withheld it, reminding me of yet another reason to take a break.

@Eric Hougland

It's not just one answer. Recently I haven't been enjoying these puzzles, at all. The good clues and answers haven't been making me smile, but the poor ones never failed to annoy me. When I saw the ridiculousness of DINDIN something in me snapped. I need to take time off from solving. Who knows, maybe I'll be back in a week.

@Eric Hougland

Recently I've been doing the puzzles out of habit, and TBH mostly so that later I could post and enjoy conversing with this fine community. If I do come back quickly, it will be because of the great people here rather than the grids themselves, which I just can't see improving without Mr Shortz retiring.

@Andrzej

I‚Äôm sorry that you‚Äôre not enjoying the puzzles themselves. 

This is a nice little corner of the internet, but fully participating in it requires some familiarity with the day‚Äôs puzzle. 

Maybe you could try solving each puzzle until it starts to feel like a slog and then revealing whatever is left?

@Eric Hougland

Hm, that sounds like a plan. I'll take a few days off, and then maybe try it this way.

@Andrzej
Honestly I'm amazed at your persistence in doing a puzzle in a non-native language! (I enjoy reading your language insights, though I don't comment myself, much.) I can't even imagine trying to do a puzzle in my second language, Japanese! Taking a break sometimes can be a much-needed refreshment. Crosswords are a game, after all, and are meant to be enjoyable. My personal benchmark is that if a game has stopped being fun or at least rewarding in some way, something has gone amiss. Best wishes and take care!
He'll be back. One week, tops.

@Andrzej

There are good days and bad days‚Ä¶

I‚Äôm reminded of a speech from Deadwood‚Ä¶

Doc Cochran:
She wants me to brace her leg so her dragging it doesn't drive you crazy.

Al Swearengen:
So what'd you tell her?

Doc Cochran:
Not to worry about your moods, that you generate those yourself and then you find your excuse for having 'em

Might just be a bad day.

@AndrzejFor my whole life my Dad would refer to it as Din Din. As in what time is din din? I miss hearing that, so today's clue brought me a smile. Dad was a Southerner, where dinner is actually at midday but he got used to it in the evening with my NYC mom. I hope you come back soon. I look forward to reading your perspective from Poland.
@Andrzej.  Just know you have made this board a more interesting and fun place.  That is no small thing!

@Sam Lyons
Yikes! I just Googled the top 100 for the year I turned 18 - which was l-o-o-o-n-g before Soundgarden was hitting the airwaves. 

Some I can't remember at all (Disco-Tex and the Sex-O-Lettes apparently had a hit with "Get Dancin' ")?

Some I wish I could forget (looking at you, John Denver, The Captain and Tennille, Minnie Ripperton)!

On the other hand, there were also some that the mere thought of instantly transports me to a magical time. Too many to list, but Cat Stevens, BTO, and Janis Ian are among them.

@Grumpy

I just checked mine.

Top 10 included 3 by Elvis and 2 by The Platters.

No. 1 and 2 were Que Sera, Sera and Blueberry Hill by Doris Day and Fats Domino, respectively.

Memories of AM radio in my freshman dorm.

@Grumpy oh this is fun! Here‚Äôs mine:

1	"The Sign"	Ace of Base
2	"I Swear"	All-4-One
3	"I'll Make Love to You"	Boyz II Men
4	"The Power of Love"	Celine Dion
5	"Hero"	Mariah Carey
6	"Stay (I Missed You)"	Lisa Loeb and Nine Stories
7	"Breathe Again"	Toni Braxton
8	"All for Love"	Bryan Adams, Rod Stewart and Sting
9	"All That She Wants"	Ace of Base
10	"Don't Turn Around" 	Ace of Base

@Sam Lyons

I am embarrassed by the top 10 from the year I was 18. There were sooooooo many better songs‚Ä¶but, here are the Billboard Top 10 (1971):

1. Joy the World, Three Dog Night
2. Maggie May/Reason to Believe, Rod Stewart
3. It‚Äôs Too Late, Carole King
4. One Bad Apple, The Osmonds
5. How Can You Mend a Broken Heart, BeeGees
6. Indian Reservation, Paul Revere & the Raiders
7. Go Away Little Girl, Donnie Osmond
8. Take Me Home, Country Roads, John Denver
9. Just My Imagination, The Temptations
10. Knock Three Times, Tony Orlando and Dawn

One clear memory from this list (I mean aside from all the angsty high school dances): At my first off-campus college party that fall, there was a young woman who sat on the floor next to record player, playing Maggie May over and over. Every time it ended, she reached over, picked up the tone arm, and started the song‚Ä¶over and over.

@Tisha Don't think that asparagus ice cream is a traditional German food! It's more of a novelty. And, yes, I believe it is made with‚Äîessentially‚Äîground up asparagus. Usually the white variety.

@Ingrid - My very first visit to Germany was in Spargelzeit, and I really love asparagus. Still a favorite memory comes from (later in life) culling bright green sprigs of wild asparagus in southern France and making omelettes of them with the neighbor‚Äôs fresh hen eggs.

As for ice cream, I make home-made black pepper ice cream, baby peas ice cream, curry and coconut ice cream, grana padano and rosemary ice cream‚Ä¶so many wonderful savories just waiting for the person bored by fruits and sugars.

My app-tracked puzzle stats say I have solved almost 8,300 NYT puzzles. I expect the actual number (including those I solved on paper or in AcrossLite) is closer to 10,000. If nothing else, I‚Äôve learned how rare the gems are.
@Eric Hougland You are good at that, Eric.

@Times Rita I actually think people here are ok with others not loving a certain puzzle.

You'll find that when the complaints come across as non-productive that they get the most push back.  Things such as...

"I hate this puzzle so im cancelling my subscription"  What are you 12?   Ya wanna cancel...Cancel...Why go find the boards and then rage quit.

"This isnt a crossword..." Fill in the blank what the complaint is...Rebuses...Missing letters...Not being symmetrical...whatever... The NYT are a premier company in the business...You may not like the format...BUT we can most certainly assure you its a crossword.

"I dont know this word so the NYT shouldnt use it"  Its hard to take anyone seriously with some of the words they dont like.

etc.

But actual discussion of the puzzle and its merits is in general appreciated here...Every puzzle cant be everyone's favorite...and statistically...one of the puzzles is going to be someone's least favorite.  It happens over 365 days a year...decades on end.

@Lewis, And although it might not augment your schwa-de-vivre, ICARUS beside ASPARAGUS may bring US some joy!

About suffering they were never wrong,
The Old Masters: how well they understood
Its human position; how it takes place
While someone else is eating or opening a window or just walking dully along

How, when the aged are reverently, passionately waiting
For the miraculous birth, there always must be
Children who did not specially want it to happen, skating
On a pond at the edge of the wood:
They never forgot
That even the dreadful martyrdom must run its course
Anyhow in a corner, some untidy spot
Where the dogs go on with their doggy life and the torturer's horse
Scratches its innocent behind on a tree.

In Brueghel's Icarus, for instance: how everything turns away
Quite leisurely from the disaster; the ploughman may
Have heard the splash, the forsaken cry, 
But for him it was not an important failure; the sun shone
As it had to on the white legs disappearing into the green
Water; and the expensive delicate ship that must have seen
Something amazing, a boy falling out of the sky,
Had somewhere to get to and sailed calmly on.

[Extinct Greek waxwing] :-) :-) :-)

@Rich in Atlanta Oh, and then stumbled across some other puzzles - all of them having a palindrome theme. Here's one - A Thursday from October, 2016 by Alan Arbesfeld. Here are some theme clue/answer examples: "Supposedly, some Australian birds can participate in the America's Cup," palindromically" EMUSSAILIASSUME "Peter the Great, Mother Teresa and Bob Marley, palindromically" ATSARANUNARASTA And a couple of other theme answers: TOOBADIHIDABOOT NOWAYAPAPAYAWON Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/20/2016&g=47&d=A And a couple of other palindrome puzzles - A Wednesday from March 17, 1999 by Myles Callum.
